This morning we set off for Pilsen (or rather Plzeň), but first we’d planned a stop just 14km south of Karlovy Vary at a little town called Loket which sits on a hill in a loop of the Ohře River. Kermit sits patiently ready to go.

We arrived at Loket at about 9:30am and parked up across the bridge. There’s minimal parking in the town so don’t bother driving in. More so today, as there was an event in town. And there’s an event at the end of this month as well – It’s Captain Jack!

On a rocky hill in a loop in the river sits the 12th century Gothic style Loket Castle, which was once known as “the Impregnable Castle of Bohemia” because of its thick walls. It’s one of the oldest stone castles in the Czech Republic.

Trivia: Charles IV often stayed at Loket castle, even though he was held in the underground prison here for two months when he was only 3 years old!

Here’s Loket from my virtual drone (aka the web!). Quite a quaint little town.

Crossing the bridge into Loket.

Car of the day came early this morning. In fact it was actually ‘cars of the day’. A rally of classic cars and motorcycles had stopped over. Here’s a taste.

A cross between Captain Mainwaring off Dad’s Army, and Radar from MASH. Kath thinks he’s gorgeous!

More lean machines.

The town centre and castle were both used as locations in the 2006 film Casino Royale, representing a town in Montenegro!

Security for a bicycle is better than no security (sorry Mike).

We walked up to the castle entrance but didn’t trek through it (there’s not a lot going on inside this one).

More cars.

Heading back down to the main drag to search for the brewery.

Here it is.

Not much happening, just a shop. This local concoction looks like a sample from the morning after.

It’s a nice day today, the temperature at Loket this morning was about 22C and getting warmer all the time. It would top out at 26-27C at Plzeň later on.

A parting shot of the castle. Battling with the glare of the sun.

The drive from Loket to Plzeň wasn’t a long one, just 81kms (1 hour 10 min). We initially drove through the green hills east of Loket before busting out into wide open spaces and letting Kermit loose. The run went quite well until we got inside of Plzeň itself where there were road works galore. Every time we wanted to turn left there was a ‘no turning’ sign in place. After encountering 3 of these, and driving aimlessly around, we spotted some cars driving through into a street that the signs were telling us not to go into. So we followed them! And it proved to be the right move. Phew.

We arrived at the accommodation 2 hours before check-in but they let us park in their underground park while we went for a walk.

Trivia: Plzeň (which is actually only about 90km from Prague) was founded in 1295 by King Wenceslaus II of Bohemia, and nowadays is the fourth most populous city in the Czech Republic with approx 170,000 residents. BUT… more importantly this IS the birthplace of Pilsner beer! More on that tomorrow.

The south and east sides of old town Plzeň town are bordered by parks. We took a stroll through the park (Šafaříkovy sady) and stumbled across these guys. Spejbl and Hurvínek (Spayble & Hoor-vee-neck) are a Czech puppet comedy duo who were created in 1920 & 1926. They actually achieved international success, and in Prague there is even a theatre named after them! Nuff said.

The Neo-Renaissance Museum of West Bohemia in Plzeň (1893–1902).

Mestský Park is on the south side of town, and that’s where we stumbled across these two nudies. This wouldn’t get past the PC brigade in NZ.

To the left, Czech composer – Bedřich Smetana (1824-1884).

The J.K. Tyl Theatre (1899-1902), aka The Great Theatre.

This Moorish-Romanesque styled Great Synagogue is the largest in the Czech Republic, the second largest in Europe, and the third largest synagogue in the World. Originally built in 1892, it was completely destroyed in WW2, so this is the reconstructed version.

This is a dead easy short stroll. Whilst looping back into the old town square we found something for Julie and Scooter. Kangaroo pies!? It also looks like they’ve borrowed the Qantas logo.

Woooaahh. Retro Rob, we’ve found the perfect business for you, my man. Established and ready to go!

Building art. WTF!

Arriving in Republic Square (Náměstí Republiky), which is one of the largest town squares in Europe (193m long x 139m wide), the standout is the massive gothic St. Bartholomew’s Cathedral, which was constructed in the late 13th century immediately after the founding of the city, and it evolved over the centuries that followed. Its tower is 102m high (335ft), making it the highest in the Czech Republic. Hmm, it seems there’s a lot of ‘largest’, ‘biggest’ and ‘highest’ going on here in Plzeň. Kath’s stomach pains will be a very good excuse not to climb the 301 steps of the tower. Well not today anyway. Maybe tomorrow.

In the old town square there are 3 of these large Golden Fountains. This one is the Greyhound Fountain. And what a magnificent backdrop!

Building art in the square.

Beautiful Neo-Renaissance and Art Nouveau influenced architecture.

Zlatá kašna Velbloud (the Camel Golden Fountain).

And then Kath spotted this above a shop. Umm.

Watch out!!

Along the side of the St. Bartholomew’s Cathedral there’s these decorative Baroque bars adorned with the heads of cherubs. Each one has a different expression, but there’s one that’s fairly worn. They say “Touch the little angel and make a wish”. Wooahh, that sounds a bit Harvey Weinstein!

Meantime the coppas are in action. A big dude with builder’s crack clamps a Porsche Carrera. I bet they just love it when they nail the big boy’s toys.

The third golden fountain is Zlatá kašna – Anděl (the Angel Golden Fountain).

Another clamping. They ARE hunting out the big boy’s toys!

The classic building in the square is the Renaissance City/Town Hall which was reconstructed between 1554-1559 after a large fire in 1507. It’s decorated with Czech rulers and the city’s coat of arms. Beautiful!

Wedding car decoration of the year.

Immediately to the left of the Town Hall is Imperial House. It is so named because when plague broke out in Prague in September 1599, Emperor Rudolf II fled the city and came to Plzeň. So until June 4, 1600, Plzen served as the capital of the Empire. Today, the Mayor’s office is on the first floor.

The St. Mary’s (Marian) plague column (1681) with the Baroque replica of Plzeň Madonna on the top in the NW corner of Republic Square.

The Neo-Renaissance Dům U Červeného srdce (House by the Red Heart) building (1894) is easily identified by a red heart in the middle of the facade.

Detail on the House by the Red Heart building.

More building art.

Down a random side street.

Along Pražská, with the oldest water monument in Plzeň at the back. This Water Tower was once part of the city fortifications.

Kath, tram!

There’s a seat over there with our name on it.

Cocktails please. Aperol Spritz CZK99 (NZ$6.60). Sex on the Beach CZK119 (NZ$7.93). Cheap as.

Our hotel is across the road, so we didn’t have far to stumble.

Muzza yells “Dead Ants!” and a local obliges.

I’ll have a beer please. CZK59 (NZ$3.93).

And another. Here’s the label. It’s their own brew – Plzenský Pašák Světlý Ležák (pronounced umm forget it). A nice drop. None of the beers I’ve had so far can be called craft beers (as in what we have in NZ). They’re more of a standard draft beer (but better than our bog standard draft beers).

7 Days says: “Plzeň synchronised swimming team gets it all wrong”.

Sorry Mike but we found Security to be “on duty” at the supermarket.

After checking in, we popped down to the local supermarket and bought some supplies. Got this stuff on a ‘let’s just try it’ based on the pictures. A beautiful spread/dip, goes good on bread or crackers. But what is it?

To all of you Crusader name hating wankers, please note the Crusader knight WITH a sword on this wine bottle. Is it a problem? No it isn’t. Get a grip! We bought a bottle and it’s chilling right now. CZK149, NZ$9.93. Must be a good!

Spirits on show. Some unusual stuff.

Grabbed one of these as well.

There’s the round up for today. Gonna chill for a bit.

Oh, almost forgot again! The step counts. Not a biggy today, but did crack the required 10K – 10,435.

Yesterday at Karlovy Vary – 15,018

Day before at Lidice & the castle – 13,213

Today we took a leisurely walk around the architecturally beautiful old town of Karlovy Vary (previously Carlsbad). This very picturesque spa town sits on the northern edge of the Slavkov Forest in the west Bohemia region of the Czech Republic. The weather today was more of the same. Sun, with showers here and there and occasional thunder. Seems to be the trend. Any rain we get never lasts, and the ground dries fast. The temperature was quite pleasant for wandering around, 24C. Higher when the sun is full on. Although it’s only 27kms from the German border, Karlovy Vary is still only 130kms from Prague! It’s a reminder that the Czech Republic is actually quite a small country.

Karlovy Vary’s numerous thermal springs have made it a popular resort since the 19th century. Our visit will zone in on the riverside spa district which is home to several colonnades / columned walkways, mineral spas and beautiful 19th-century architecture.

The trivia: Population – 50,000. The town sits on the confluence of the rivers Ohře and Teplá. It was named after Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor and King of Bohemia, who founded the city in 1370 – by mistake really. He was hunting deer in the area and one of his hounds fell into a bubbling thermal hot spring. Don’t panic, the dog not only survived, but his wounded leg was miraculously repaired. Charles recognised the healing powers and it was game on for a new town.

Over the following centuries its elegant spas became ‘the’ place to go for the royal and the wealthy. Visitors included Tsar Peter the Great of Russia, Karl Marx, Emperor Franz Josef I, Beethoven, Chopin, Casanova, Goethe, Wagner, Tolstoy, Freud, and now us. Many aristocrats even built elaborate mansions for their periodic visits. We spotted heaps of them.

Needless to say, Karlovy Vary became famous for its natural mineral and thermal hot water springs (there are 13 main springs, about 300 smaller springs!). Apparently, they were believed to have medicinal benefits, so this was enough to bring in the crowds.

Righto… we set off down a walking track in front of our accommodation. The track linked to a road, and within 2 minutes we were on the east side of the Tepla River.

Looking back up at our accommodation. On a Trip Advisor tip off we managed to snare room 7 at the Villa Rosa. It’s the one at the top in the middle, with three doors that open to a long balcony. A great beer drinking spot (as tested later in the day).

A view from the track. Our plan was to wander along the river until a point near where it meets the Ohře River. We’ll veer off and check out the main shopping street until we reach Becherplatz (more on that later), then circle back and take in points of interest at the other end of the old town area.

The ‘as you do’ photo before the crowds arrive.

Sadly, they didn’t have this in Kath’s size. Gutted.

Below: The oldest baths in Karlovy Vary once stood on this site – now known as the Market Colonnade. The Swiss style structure seen today dates back to 1879 and now houses the seeps of three mineral springs. Apparently, Emperor Charles IV himself healed his ailing limbs with the waters of these springs which was named after him. Kath was busting to get a ‘Becher’ cup to try the mineral water (coz her gut has been playing up, and she was looking for that miracle cure!). But the shops aren’t quite open so we walked on.

The Holy Trinity Column (1715) in beautiful surroundings.

Inside the Market Colonnade.

To drink the supposedly health-restoring sulphurous waters, you can buy a fancy porcelain spa cup (lázeňský pohárek) aka Becher with its sipping spout protruding from the handle. Boom, instant souvenir! The locals are probably sitting back pissing themselves laughing at the tourists supping out of these odd-looking cups. We just need a seller to open (and there’s heaps of them!).

Hold on, what’s this. Surely not a racist souvenir shop?? Am I allowed to enter?

Horse!

Yup there’s a horse standing outside the Mill Colonnade (Mlýnská kolonáda) which is the largest colonnade here and houses the seeps of five mineral springs. This stone colonnade, built in Pseudo-Renaissance style, is decorated with 12 sandstone statues representing the months of the year. The original structure (1792) was replaced with this one in 1881.

Ok here’s a shop that’s opened up, and Kath spotted the Becher cup most suited to a Wino member. Sidetracking for a mo. Note the Russian writing on the wall. I read there’s been a heap of Russian investment in the old town area, so it’s become very popular with Russian visitors. Walking around, you regularly see signs in Cyrillic characters (the alphabet used in Russia) so clearly the ‘investors’ don’t see integration as a thing. Hmm this place gives the impression of a Russian enclave in the heart of Central Europe! Maybe their investment is becoming just a little too dominant? And why is that? Well before WW2 there was a strong German influence in the town, but afterwards the German population was forcibly evicted, and the Communists inherited the area. In 1951 the impressive Grandhotel Pupp (seen further down below) was even renamed Grandhotel Moscow (until 2014). Since the disintegration of the Soviet Union and the end of communism in Czechoslovakia the number of Russians buying property and opening businesses in Karlovy Vary is still steadily increasing. Interesting. There must be something magic in that water! And it also explains the grumpy nature of some of the ‘investors’. We sat at a place for lunch today, and within 3 minutes had 3 instances of shit service from a bloke who appeared to me to be Russian (There’s a different look). Grumpy, no smile, no personality. We got up and walked out. Message delivered.

Kath’s happy, coz she has her Becher and is testing the water in one of the seeps in the Mill Colonnade. The temperature at this particular seep was 56C.

In goes the piping hot natural spring water. It tastes marginally sulphury, but not. Hard to explain. Drinkable (that’s all). And there were heaps wandering around with Bechers sipping away hoping some miracle health benefit occurs. Did it fix Kath’s gut pain? Dunno. She went to a pharmacy and got some Gaviscon, so who knows.

The very shallow Teplá River with Mill Colonnade to the right.

Speaking of medicinal benefits. At the right end of the Mill Colonnade there’s a large green bottle shaped booth that sells Becherovka. Pronounced “Beh-here-offka” with the ‘Beh’ sounding like ‘bed’ without the d. So, what is it? Well it’s an alcoholic drink (do I have your attention?) that’s been produced here in Karlovy Vary since 1807. Apparently, it was originally marketed as a digestive aid (yeah right). It’s made from a secret recipe based on a wide variety of herbs and spices. They say that only two people know the secret of the entire production process. Cut to the chase… its alcohol content is 38% ABV (76 proof). Serve it chilled.

Well it’d be rude not to taste it, so I bought a small bottle later on in the day from this very ‘bottle’ shop. Yup, they sell from inside it. I’ll probably try it soon, so keep reading to get the lowdown. fyi you can buy it in NZ (700ml for $45-$50).

Bechers – everywhere!

The Orchard Colonnade, which we found (oddly) at the park! (Dvořák Park).

Meantime by the lake in the park… a skinny dipper!

Smetana Park leads down to Elizabeth Spa. As you’d imagine, there are heaps of spas here, most are hidden away in hotels. Seems that most visitors drink the mineral water rather than bathe in it. Elisabeth Spa (1906) is named after Empress Elisabeth (aka Sissi). Elisabeth Baths is the biggest consumer of the hot mineral water in the town (20% of the total quantity). There’s no end of treatments available here if you’re keen to fork out.

The pedestrian-only street named T. G. Masaryka.

A shopping centre missed by Kath.

Tomáš Garrigue Masaryk, the first President of Czechoslovakia.

Becherplatz is at the top of the street. It’s the result of an extensive reconstruction of a former 170-year-old distillery producing the aforementioned Becherovka liqueur.

And here it is! Btw. Jan Becher is the name of the company that started making Becherovka over 200 years back. Apparently, Josef Bercher, a local pharmacist started selling a medicinal tonic which was basically his own bitters-based recipe. The rest is history.

7 Days says: Man tries to blend in with building to avoid wife, who is trying to blend in with building to avoid husband.

We went inside for a peek. Aside from this area there’s shops selling Becherovka in all shapes and forms, as well as all the accessories you can think of.

Selfie under another big bottle.

We decided to loop back to where we started via a side street. Man, there’s some seriously impressive buildings around here. The area we were heading into is aptly named Castle Hill.

Now if you want proof the Russians are here, look no further. Check out the magnificent Saint Peter and Paul Cathedral (1893-97). This elaborate Russian Orthodox church with its golden domes is the country’s largest and most important orthodox church. Funded by local Russian and Serbian nobility and entrepreneurs.

Car of the day!

We’ve now looped around the side of a hill and back to where we started. Quite a pleasant walk, with only a little bit of rain thrown in. We learned quickly to take umbrellas out as a matter of course!

Check this out.

Kath at the Market Colonnade.

It was time to check out the star attraction, but dark clouds are closing in. There’s some more rain coming, and this looks like a decent amount.

We popped inside of the Hot Spring Colonnade (Vřídelní kolonáda) building which houses the most famous Hot Spring in Karlovy Vary. The spring has been covered over since 1774, and in 1975 they built this modern structure over it. Inside is the Pramen Vřídlo Geyser which, when excited, can gush 72C water to a height of 12 metres. Well it wasn’t gushing diddly sqwat today. It has been temporarily capped to allow for some construction work to be done. Bugger! Even the seeps in the adjoining room were turned off.

At the other end of the building there’s a smaller outdoor version spurting hot water into the air.

We’d just left the building and the rain came down. Heavy! The brollies were doing well. We ducked into a side ally where Muzza found somewhere to hide. Kath says “But we don’t have our togs”. And the problem is? 🙂 Kath wins.
